awd_abstract_narration:
Symbiotic bacteria impact numerous aspects of host biology. One major question is the role of early colonizing symbionts (hereafter referred to as pioneer symbionts) in primordial host development and microbial community recruitment and cohesiveness. In contrast to the diverse microbial consortia harbored within the digestive tracts of omnivorous organisms, the crop of the blood-feeding European medicinal leech (Hirudo verbana) contains a predominantly two-member microbial community consisting of the Proteobacteria Aeromonas veronii and the Bacteroidetes Rikenella sp.. The leech digestive system has a simple morphology and limited immunological capabilities. These characteristics combined with the available genetic tools make it an experimentally accessible model system to examine fundamental aspects of symbiosis. This project examines the role of the pioneer symbiont A. veronii in influencing host embryogenesis and preparing the digestive tract for the later colonizing Rikenella. Using microscopic techniques and gene expression analyses, the work will characterize the colonization and proliferation of A. veronii during host oral and gastrointestinal development. Comparative studies of symbiotic and aposymbiotic (i.e. devoid of pioneer symbionts) leeches will investigate the extent to which A. veronii influences host morphological, physiological and functional maturation as well as microbial community dynamics. 

The broader impacts of this research include the integrative training of graduate and NSF Robert NOYCE pre-service teaching undergraduates, as well as high school students representing traditionally underrepresented groups in the sciences. To expose the community at large to the significant implications of symbiosis towards biodiversity, prominent scientists in symbiosis research will be incorporated into a university-wide seminar series. The results of this research will be disseminated at various meetings, in publications and publicized on the Rio laboratory website. Lastly, a teaching outcome will be incorporated into classroom environments.

por.por_cntn:
Mutualistic bacteria enhance animal biology in many essential ways. Although transmission is instrumental to the persistence of these important relations through generations, little is known about mechanisms that enable the recruitment of specific partners at appropriate times. In contrast to the diverse symbionts (collectively referred to as the microbiota) harbored within the digestive tract of most animals, the European medicinal leech (Hirudo spp.) contains a predominantly two-member community (the Proteobacterium Aeromonas veronii and the Bacteroidetes Mucinovorans hirudinis) making it a powerful model system to identify mechanisms involved in symbiont acquisition due its natural simplicity and experimental accessibility.

Intellectual merit

Using genetic, molecular and microscopic techniques, the mechanistic basis for the acquisition of the digestive tract microbiota through leech development was examined. We found that oral contact with cyclically produced leech mucosal secretions, to which conspecific leeches are highly attracted, complements imperfect parental transmission during early host development. Although dominated by Proteobacteria and Bacteroidetes, a number of other bacteria were also identified within secretions suggesting the presence of host-generated selectivity factors to ward off unwanted microbial residents. The A. veronii population within mucosal secretions was found to originate from the host digestive tract and to proliferate synchronously with shedding frequency, demonstrating the coupling of partner biology. Further symbiont-free leeches (i.e. lacking their normal gut microbiota) display high-risk behavior not normally observed with leeches, which we hypothesized to increase their likelihood of encountering the mucus of conspecifics. Using RNA sequencing and immunostaining, stress response and nutrient acquisition genes were identified as pivotal towards the local adaptation of A. veronii to mucus. This mixed mode of transmission, coupling both parental and environmental routes, is analogous to the microbiota recruitment of other animals. Our results are relevant in the broader context because shed mucus is used for the transmission of a spectrum of microbial associations ranging from beneficial to pathogenic. Understanding the factors that underlie the success of mixed transmission will be instrumental to the development of strategies to promote beneficial symbioses.

Broader impacts:

K-12 outreach programs on microbial symbiosis were distributed to historically disadvantaged students throughout WV. In collaboration with a Robert NOYCE pre-service undergraduate, a Microbial Symbiosis teaching module (scalable to various classroom environments) was created, advertised in a WV Science Teacher (WVSTA) Lab Notes publication, and made freely available (http://www.as.wvu.edu/~rrio/Site/Teaching_unit.html). Symbiosis seminars, aimed at enhancing faculty and student understanding of the significant biological and ecological contributions of microbiotas, were given by outside researchers. Microbiota research was also integrated into two WVU undergrad/grad Biology classes; “Evolution of Infectious Diseases” and “Microbial Symbiosis”. This project served in the training of four high school students, six undergraduates and three graduate students.
